page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY OF LINTON
page.content: The earliest settlement of Linton dates from the Iron age.Various bone implements were discovered at the site.There is also evidence for Roman and Saxon settlements.Skeletons and artefacts from both periods have been found. The word Linton means "flax-town"in Anglo-Saxon. The earliest written record of Linton dates from the Domesday book of 1086,but we can see many buildings and sites that give us clues to Linton's age. The church (St.Mary the virgin) dates from the early 12th century.Near to the church we can see evidence of a ford. Along the High Street,which follows an ancient routeway,there are many timber framed buildings.Chandler's,one of the oldest,dates from the 13th century.The Guildhall,dating from the 16th century is another fine example.
